rip somebody/something ↔ off.translation: to charge someone too much money for something
The agency really ripped us off.
Somebody had come in and ripped off the TV and stereo.
to take words, ideas etc from someone else’s work and use them in your own work as if they were your own ideas
The meal was a rip-off and the service was appalling.
music, art, films etc that are rip-offs copy something else without admitting that they are copies
a rip-off of a hit movie
to charge someone too much money for something, or sell someone a product that is faulty
We all hate being ripped off.
The survey found that most dieters thought diet programs were a big rip-off.
something that is a copy of something else
The high street stores are selling cheap rip-offs of his designs.
